description: Safety protocols, outage procedures, equipment guidelines, and technical requirements

articles.title: How to Report a Power Outage
articles.content: To report a power outage, contact the PUD immediately at (360) 452-9771 or toll-free at (800) 542-7859. You can also report outages through the SmartHub mobile app or website. Check the online Outage Map at smarthub.clallampud.net/maps/OutageWebMap to see current outages in your area. Advanced meters automatically report outages even when you're away from home, helping the PUD respond faster to restore power.
articles.author: Operations

articles.title: Transformer Clearance and Landscaping Guidelines
articles.content: When landscaping near PUD equipment: Do not fence, landscape, or build structures within 10 feet of the front and 3 feet from sides and back of transformers or other PUD equipment. Obstructing airflow can damage equipment and cause delays in service restoration. Never paint PUD equipment. The PUD will remove obstructions that impede work access. If unsure about your landscaping plans, call (360) 452-9771 or toll-free (800) 542-7859 before starting work.
articles.author: Operations

articles.title: Meter Space and Access Requirements
articles.content: Proper meter access requires: Clear space in front of meter equipment at least 36 inches deep, as wide as the equipment (minimum 36 inches), and at least 6 feet 6 inches high. Pathways must be minimum 2 feet wide. If walkway crosses a ditch wider than 6 feet, a structurally sound handrail is required. Meters must be readily removable (not plastered or built-in) and not recessed behind exterior walls. Meters in alleys or driveways must be flush mounted and protected from vehicular traffic. Customers are responsible for costs of repairs or replacement due to neglect, carelessness, or misuse.
articles.author: Operations

articles.title: Low Water Pressure Troubleshooting
articles.content: If water pressure seems lower than normal: Turn on faucets one at a time throughout the house and outside to determine if pressure is low everywhere or in specific areas. If low in some areas only, remove and clean faucet screens and check for partially closed shut-off valves. If no improvement, a plumber may need to remove restrictions within your home's plumbing. If pressure is low throughout the house, please call the PUD at (360) 452-9771 for assistance.
articles.author: Water Operations

articles.title: Advanced Meter Benefits and Features
articles.content: Advanced meters provide numerous benefits: Enhanced customer privacy with reduced need for property access. Consistent billing cycles with no estimates. More accurate bills than older electromechanical meters. Faster service connection and disconnection. Enhanced employee safety. Energy theft protection. Automatic outage detection and reporting even when you're away from home. Improved power quality investigations with remote diagnostics. Faster outage restoration. Reduced carbon footprint by eliminating many field trips. Over 119 million advanced meters (72% of US customers) have been installed nationwide as of 2022.
articles.author: Metering Department

articles.title: Advanced Meter Opt-Out Program
articles.content: Customers may opt out of advanced meters and receive a digital meter without remote-read capability. The opt-out program includes a monthly fee to cover additional costs for manual meter reading. The PUD will read the meter every other month, estimating between reads. Opt-out is not available for: customers on Net Metering or Pre-Pay programs, those with tampered meters, poly-phase or demand meter service, locations with continuous service programs for landlords, customers who violate facility access policy, or after any field trip for non-payment disconnection. Submit a Remote-Read or Advanced Meter Opt-Out Form to enroll.
articles.author: Metering Department

articles.title: Advanced Meter Safety and Radio Frequency
articles.content: Advanced meters operate at 900 MHz Radio Frequency in the unlicensed UHF band with maximum transmission of 0.5 watts. Total transmission time averages only 12 minutes per year. Standing in front of an advanced meter for an entire year equals the RF exposure of a short phone call or streaming a short video. Both RF and power line carrier meters are UL-certified. The meters only transmit: total power consumed, instantaneous voltage, device numeric identification, and disconnect position (on/off). No personal usage data or private information is transmitted.
articles.author: Metering Department

articles.title: SmartHub Account Portal Features
articles.content: SmartHub is the PUD's customer portal available on the website and as a mobile app. Features include: Track your energy usage in real-time. Report power outages. Pay your bill online. Set up autopay or payment reminders. View billing history. Manage your account preferences. Access usage data for SmartPay prepay accounts with daily balance alerts. SmartHub provides greater control over your account and helps you monitor and manage your energy consumption.
articles.author: Customer Service

articles.title: SmartPay Prepay Account Program
articles.content: SmartPay is a prepay electric account where you pay for electricity before using it. Benefits include: No due dates or monthly billing statements. Pay what you can when you can. Receive alerts when balance is low. Track daily usage through SmartHub mobile app. No deposits required. Avoid late fees and disconnection notices. Great option for budget-conscious customers who want to manage energy costs in real-time. Ideal for customers having difficulty with traditional billing cycles.
articles.author: Customer Service

articles.title: Planned Outage Notifications
articles.content: The PUD schedules planned outages for necessary maintenance, upgrades, and system improvements. Customers affected by planned outages receive advance notification when possible. Check the PUD website calendar for upcoming planned outages in your area. Planned outages are typically scheduled during daytime hours and off-peak seasons when possible to minimize inconvenience. The PUD works to complete planned maintenance efficiently to restore power as quickly as possible.
articles.author: Operations

articles.content: PUD Contact Information - Main Office (Sequim): (360) 452-9771. Toll-Free: (800) 542-7859. Forks Office: (360) 374-6201. Clallam Bay/Sekiu Office: (360) 963-2223. Pay by Phone: (855) 943-3644. Office Hours: Monday through Thursday, 7am to 5pm (Main and Forks offices). Clallam Bay/Sekiu office open Wednesdays 8am to 4pm. For after-hours emergencies including power outages, call the main number. Customer Service Email: CustomerServiceInquiry@clallampud.net
articles.author: Customer Service

articles.title: PUD Service Territory and Coverage Area
articles.content: Clallam County PUD serves electric, water, wastewater, and broadband services throughout Clallam County, Washington. Main service areas include Sequim, Port Angeles, Forks, and Clallam Bay/Sekiu regions. The PUD operates as a public utility district, meaning it is owned by the customers it serves and governed by elected commissioners. Service territory boundaries can be verified by contacting the PUD or checking the service availability map on the website.
articles.author: Administration

articles.title: High Electric Bill Troubleshooting
articles.content: If your electric bill seems unusually high, consider these factors: Winter heating costs increase as outside temperatures drop. Home insulation values, heating system efficiency, air infiltration, and home size all affect energy use. Check for: malfunctioning thermostat, space heaters running continuously, water heater issues, or phantom loads from electronics. The PUD offers free energy audits to help identify efficiency improvements. Review your usage history in SmartHub to compare with previous months. Contact the PUD if you believe there's a metering error.
articles.author: Energy Services

articles.title: Energy Efficiency Rebates and Programs
articles.content: The PUD offers rebates and incentives for energy-efficient upgrades including: Heat pump installations, weatherization improvements, energy-efficient appliances, LED lighting upgrades, and insulation improvements. These programs help reduce energy consumption, lower utility bills, and benefit the environment. Eligibility requirements and rebate amounts vary by program. Low-income customers may qualify for additional assistance. Contact the PUD for current program details, application forms, and to schedule an energy audit to identify improvement opportunities.
articles.author: Energy Services

articles.title: Downed Power Line Safety Protocol
articles.content: If you encounter a downed power line: STAY AWAY - assume all downed lines are energized and dangerous. Keep at least 35 feet away from downed lines. Never touch anything or anyone in contact with a downed line. Do not attempt to move downed lines or debris near them. Call 911 immediately and report the location. Then call the PUD at (360) 452-9771 or (800) 542-7859. Keep others away from the area until help arrives. If a power line falls on your vehicle, stay inside unless there is fire - if you must exit, jump clear without touching the vehicle and ground simultaneously.
articles.author: Safety Department
